item.title: Covid-19: A-level and GCSE results to be decided by teachers
item.description: A combination of mock exams, coursework and essays will be used to decide grades in England this year.

item.title: Johnson and Johnson vaccine: FDA finds the single-shot jab safe
item.description: US regulators say Johnson and Johnson's single-shot vaccine is safe, and could be approved in days.

item.title: Australia passes law to make Google and Facebook pay for news
item.description: The world-first law is designed to make the tech giants pay news publishers for content.

item.title: Brit Awards change rules thanks to pop star Rina Sawayama
item.description: Pop star Rina Sawayama protested after being told she was "not British enough" for UK music awards.

item.title: How 30,000 elephant 'selfies' will help in conservation
item.description: Researchers are developing new technology to help reduce human-elephant conflicts.

item.title: UK 4G smartphone owners may be due £480m pay-out
item.description: Some 29 million people in the UK could be entitled to up to £30 back on Apple or Samsung smartphones.

item.title: Government urged to ensure convicted sex offenders cannot work as tutors
item.description: There has been an increase in private tuition during the pandemic but concerns remain about the checks in place.

item.title: Covid: Half with cancer signs didn't contact GP in first wave
item.description: Symptoms left unchecked included lumps, changes to moles and coughing up blood, a survey finds.

item.title: Marcus Rashford interview nets BBC scoop of the year at RTS awards
item.description: The England striker spoke about growing up in poverty as he campaigned for free school meals.

item.title: Covid-19: Adverts urge people to 'keep going' and remain at home
item.description: It comes amid falling cases, the vaccine rollout and the launch of the roadmap out of lockdown.

item.title: GameStop surges again as Reddit crashes temporarily
item.description: Trading in GameStop shares halted minutes before markets closed but jumped again in late trading.

item.title: Ikea aims to launch delayed 'Buy Back' scheme in UK
item.description: UK consumers will soon be able to sell back used items with the aim of reducing waste.

item.title: The Papers: Teachers get 'sweeping powers' and Sunak's 'giveaway'
item.description: The papers focus on new rules to be announced later which will let teachers decide exam grades in England.

item.title: The colourful fridges popping up on American streets
item.description: Local communities in the US have come up with a novel way to help feed those going hungry.

item.title: Inside a domestic violence call centre
item.description: Calls to a major domestic violence charity increased by more than 50 per cent during the pandemic in 2020.

item.title: Mother and son become tap-dance lockdown sensation
item.description: Lizzi Gee and her eight-year-old son Rufus say tap routines are one positive to come out of lockdown.

item.title: Kenya: A sustainable solution to locust swarms?
item.description: An NGO is training and paying communities in Kenya to catch locusts, so they can be turned into animal feed.

item.title: Man Utd & England striker Marcus Rashford receives prestigious Gold Blue Peter badge
item.description: Watch the moment Manchester United and England striker Marcus Rashford is awarded the prestigious Gold Blue Peter badge for his work in making a difference to young people’s lives.

item.title: Builders at Seville bar uncover '12th Century bathhouse'
item.description: The discovery of the preserved skylights and paintings was "completely unexpected", experts say.

item.title: Covid-19: 'Getting married is the most important thing'
item.description: What will the lifting restrictions on weddings mean to couples and those in the industry?

item.title: Rare bird: 'Half-male, half-female' cardinal snapped in Pennsylvania
item.description: Jamie Hill said taking the stunning photos of the northern cardinal was "once in a lifetime".

item.title: The disabled influencers making their mark on social media
item.description: Brands are starting to embrace social media influencers with disabilities to target the "purple pound".

item.title: Brazilian Amazon: Juma descendants of 'last warrior' vow to carry on legacy
item.description: After the death of the last male member of an indigenous group, his grandchildren take an unusual step.

item.title: Biden's Covid stimulus plan: It costs $2tn but what's in it?
item.description: Democrats are working on a massive package of measures to help the US through the pandemic.

item.title: Budget 2021: 'If I have to pay £13,000, it will destroy my shop'
item.description: Struggling shops warn they may have to shut if business rates are brought back at the Budget.

item.title: Looming battle for Yemen's Marib city risks humanitarian disaster
item.description: A rebel attack on the government's northern stronghold of Marib threatens mass displacement.

item.title: Have Australians fallen out of love with Sydney and Melbourne?
item.description: Figures show Australians are moving out of the large cities in search of a better quality of life.

item.title: The Simpsons creator Matt Groening on equality, memes and monorails
item.description: BBC Radio 1 Newsbeat sits down for a Zoom chat with Matt Groening.

item.title: Dominant Man City in control of Champions League last-16 tie with 19th win in a row
item.description: Manchester City make it 19 wins in a row with another utterly dominant display against Borussia Monchengladbach

item.title: India v England: Michael Vaughan says tourists 'batted like rabbits in headlights'
item.description: England's batsmen played "like rabbits in headlights" on the first day of the third Test against India in Ahmedabad, says former captain Michael Vaughan.

item.title: Alli impresses as Tottenham cruise through in Europa League
item.description: Dele Alli scores a spectacular overhead kick as Tottenham cruise into the Europa League last 16 with an 8-1 aggregate win over Wolfsberger.

item.title: Holloway breaks Jackson's 27-year-old 60m hurdles world record - highlights & report
item.description: American Grant Holloway breaks the indoor 60m hurdles world record at the final World Indoor Tour event in Madrid, Spain.

item.title: Joshua fight no closer to being agreed, says Fury
item.description: WBC champion Tyson Fury says a fight against Anthony Joshua is no closer to being agreed than it was a year ago.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: The prime minister has announced a plan for how the lockdown will be lifted in England.

item.title: Covid: When will schools reopen?
item.description: All students in England can return to classrooms from 8 March as part of the plans to ease lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: How are weddings working around the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: Covid: When can pubs and restaurants reopen?
item.description: Hospitality venues are set to gradually open up in the Spring under lockdown easing plans.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: 'Vaccine passports': Will I need one for going out, work and travel?
item.description: The government is reviewing whether venues can ask for proof of vaccination or a negative test.

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday in the UK or travel abroad?
item.description: The government has unveiled its plans for unlocking UK restrictions, including holiday travel.

item.title: My daughter's shielding - should she return to school? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: As the UK cautiously unlocks, experts will review the evidence on when and where masks are needed.

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased in England. When will services like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Schools reopening: How at risk are children?
item.description: BBC's Health reporter Laura Foster explains what we know currently about how children are affected by the virus.

item.title: How could children make up for lost school time?
item.description: A massive task lies ahead for schools as they try to make up for teaching time lost during the pandemic.

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: Have lockdowns affected my child's physical and mental health?
item.description: Should parents of under-fives worry about Covid restrictions harming their child's development?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: More people have been added to the clinically extremely vulnerable list in England. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Has the NHS got enough of the right PPE?
item.description: Who needs it - and does the UK health service have the right kit?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 18 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Two approved Covid vaccines are being rolled out across the UK, so when might you get one?

item.title: Is the Covid vaccine safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Covid: Can you catch the virus outside?
item.description: The risks of catching Covid indoors are well-known, but what are the chances of being infected outdoors?

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covax: How will Covid vaccines be shared around the world?
item.description: A scheme to distribute Covid-19 vaccines globally is under way. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being mass tested for new variants?
item.description: The government hopes "surge" testing will reduce transmission of a new variant of Covid-19.

item.title: What is a challenge trial and why do we need them?
item.description: Some volunteers in the UK will be deliberately infected with coronavirus in a "challenge trial".

item.title: Covid: Claims vaccinations harm fertility unfounded
item.description: Social-media posts - some described as "scare stories" - are based on misunderstandings, experts say.

item.title: Fake Covid videos 'will cost lives'
item.description: Sima Kotecha follows the origins of a "dangerous" viral video about a false Covid-19 treatment.

item.title: Covid: How will we know if the vaccine is working?
item.description: Deaths are falling faster for the over-80s - but does that mean the vaccine is working?

item.title: Netflix and Anna Delvey: The race to secure the story of New York's 'fake heiress'
item.description: How Anna Sorokin's life rights became hot property.
